item.title: A Probabilistic Framework for the Erdos-Kac Theorem
item.description: arXiv:2509.04102v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The Erdos-Kac theorem, a foundational result in probabilistic number theory, states that the number of prime factors of an integer follows a Gaussian distribution. In this paper we develop and analyze probabilistic models for "random integers" to study the mechanisms underlying this theorem. We begin with a simple model, where each prime p is chosen as a divisor with probability 1/p in a sequence of independent trials. A preliminary analysis shows that this construction almost surely yields an integer with infinitely many prime factors. To create a tractable framework, we study a truncated version Nx = product of p<=x of p^Xp, where Xp are independent Bernoulli(1/p) random variables. We prove an analogue of the Erdos-Kac theorem within this framework, showing that the number of prime factors omega(Nx) satisfies a central limit theorem with mean and variance asymptotic to log log x.
item.dc:creator: Mantha Sai Gopal

item.title: On Taylor-like Estimates for Chebyshev Series Approximations of $e^x$
item.description: arXiv:2401.10169v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Polynomial series approximations are a central theme in approximation theory due to their utility in an abundance of numerical applications. The two types of series, which are featured most prominently, are Taylor series expansions and expansions derived based on families of $L^{2}-$orthogonal polynomials on bounded intervals. Traditionally, however, the properties of these series are studied in an isolated manner and most results on the $L^{2}-$based approximations are restricted to the interval of approximation. In many applications, theoretical guarantees require global estimates. Since these often follow trivially from Taylor's remainder theorem, Taylor's series is often favored in these applications. Its suboptimal numerical performance on compact intervals, however, ultimately results in such numerical algorithms being suboptimal. We show that "Taylor-like" bounds valid outside of the interval of approximation may be derived for the important case of $e^{x}$ and Chebyshev polynomials on $[-1,1]$ and provide links to substantial numerical applications.
item.dc:creator: Ale\v{s} Wodecki

item.title: An Identity Linking Bernoulli Numbers, Stirling Numbers of the First Kind, and Bessel Numbers of the First Kind
item.description: arXiv:2505.22819v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We prove the identity \[ \sum_{k=0}^{n} 2^{\,n-k} s(n,k) \, B_k \;=\; \sum_{k=0}^{n} b(n,k)\,\frac{(-1)^k\,k!}{k+1}, \] which connects Bernoulli numbers, Stirling numbers of the first kind, and Bessel numbers of the first kind. The proof proceeds via an operational identity for $(x^{-1}D)^n$, an expansion of a quadratic-step product in the falling factorial basis, and coefficient extraction using Faulhaber's formula and Stirling numbers of the first kind.
item.dc:creator: Abdelhay Benmoussa

item.title: Infinite integrals in terms of series
item.description: arXiv:2506.19867v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this work we derive and evaluate some infinite integrals involving the product of a generalized logarithm and polynomial functions in the denominator. These integrals are expressed in terms of finite series involving the Hurwitz-Lerch zeta function. We produce special cases of these integrals in terms of other special functions and fundamental constants.
